title.narrative: Conservation of 20th-Century Ethnographic Objects at Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum

description.narrative: Housed in a former school turned prison and torture site, the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum honors the victims of Cambodias 1975-1979 genocide. This project includes the conservation of textiles and training in preventive conservation for museum staff. It directly supports the U.S. embassys efforts to build capacity at the museum, which endures as a reminder of the atrocities committed by the Khmer Rouge.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Environment - General
Site preservation

title.narrative: LS Victim Case Management System (VCMS) Global Expansion

description.narrative: The Victim Case Management System (VCMS) Program aims to enable the creation of a global community of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and civil society organizations (CSOs) committed to implementing consistent data collection and professionalized record keeping on their work to care for victims and populations vulnerable to human trafficking. This project seeks to connect these key actors and facilitate the community-driven creation of best practices around data-informed victim protection and care. Through the consistent collection of critical information on instances of human trafficking, we also seek to facilitate increased opportunities for frontline NGOs and CSOs to contribute to data sharing and aggregation projects (such as International Organization for Migration (IOM)'s Counter Trafficking Data Collaborative (CTDC) that increase the ability of key stakeholders to respond to the issue.

title.narrative: Conservation of the 10th-Century Temple of Phnom Bakheng, Phase 5

description.narrative: Phnom Bakheng temple is the most visited temple at Angkor Archaeological Parka World Heritage siteand one of the greatest cultural achievements of the Khmer Kingdom. This project, which continues work begun under previous Ambassadors Fund grants and involves the conservation of the temples east faade, directly supports the treaty between the United States and Cambodia concerning the looting and illicit trafficking of Khmer antiquities and other Cambodian cultural property.

title.narrative: Documentation of Newly Discovered Angkorian Sites on Kulen Mountain

description.narrative: Phnom Kulen is a culturally important mountain range near Angkor Archaeological Park. About 30 archeological sites and many more lesser-known and unidentified sites ranging in date from the 8th to the 12th century are endangered by subsistence farming and looting in the area. This project includes site mapping, assessment, and a heritage protection education and outreach program.

title.narrative: Documentation of 9th-15th-Century Khmer Antiquities

description.narrative: To support the documentation of Khmer antiquities from the 9th to the 15th century and the establishment of a comprehensive inventory of known artifacts in Cambodia. Looters are destroying Cambodias cultural heritage, targeting archaeological sites, temples, museums, and other collections. This project focuses on centralizing information currently maintained at various institutions in a combined national register of antiquities.

title.narrative: Documentation of the Phloy and the Khaen, Two Traditional Mouth Organs of Cambodia

description.narrative: The Phloy and the Khaen mouth organs are critically endangered as only a few musicians of each instrument are still alive today. This project, which includes the documentation, directly supports the Embassy's efforts to raise awareness of the significance of these instruments in Cambodian culture and to demonstrate U.S. respect for Cambodia's cultural heritage.

description.narrative: One of Cambodias most important genocide memorials, the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum preserves hard evidence of the brutal torture and murder of Cambodian civilians by the Khmer Rouge regime. title.narrative: Conservation of the 10thCentury Temple of Phnom Bakheng, Phase 3

description.narrative: Phonm Bakeng is the most visited temple at Angkor Archaeological Park and one of the greatest cultural achievements of the Khmer Kingdom, but the harsh tropical climate and heavy tourism have taken their toll on the ancient monument. Phase 3 of this on-going project involves the conservation of the temple's east faade, central shrine, and drainage system.
